Based on this information alone it is impossible for me to accurately determine either time period or geographical region. This particular play was published in 1662, and thus we can assume that its setting must be after circa 1600 B.C.E (the earliest possible starting point) but before the year of publication.
A title like "La mort de Baltazar, roy de Babilone" suggests a Middle Eastern location because Babylon is historically located near modern-day Iraq. However, this information alone isn't enough to accurately identify geographic region or time period.

If you want me to try and identify a time period for this play based on its title alone, then I can make the following guess:

"Babylon is an ancient Mesopotamian city located in present-day Iraq. It was founded around 2300 B.C.E., but it reached its peak under King Hammurabi (reigned c.1792–1750 BC). After Babylon fell to Assyria, Nabonidus briefly held the throne as a last king of independent Babylonia and sought refuge with distant tribes like the Medes."

This means that if this play were set in ancient times it would be located somewhere around Mesopotamia (modern-day Iraq) between 2300 B.C.E. and c.1750 BC.
